'''JMicron Technology Corporation'''([[Chinese language|Chinese]]: æºå¾®ç§æ) is a [[Taiwan]]ese manufacturer of [[integrated circuits]] which mostly produces [[Serial ATA]] and related controller chips.<ref>[http://www.jmicron.com/Product_list.htm JMicron's product list]</ref>
Its chips are used by a number of companies, such as [[ASUS]],<ref>[http://support.asus.com/download/download.aspx?SLanguage=en-us&model=M2V-MX&type=map&mapindex=4 Reference to JMicron on ASUS website.]</ref> [[Gigabyte Technology|Gigabyte]], and [[MSI]]<ref>[http://www.msicomputer.com/product/p_spec.asp?model=P965_Neo-F&class=mb MSI's original P965 Neo-F with JMicron controller]</ref> in [[PC motherboard]]s, though because of difficulties, newer MSI models have moved to using integrated [[Marvell]] controllers.<ref>[http://global.msi.com.tw/index.php?func=proddesc&prod_no=1275&maincat_no=1&cat2_no=170&cat3_no=2 MSI P965 Neo-F version 2, with JMicron controller replaced]</ref>
==SSD Controllers== JMicron's JMF601 and JMF602 SATA [[flash controller]]s were reported to have issues with write latency, causing a stuttering problem.<ref>[http://www.dailytech.com/OCZ+Once+Again+Slashes+the+Price+of+Core+Series+SSDs/article12993.htm OCZ Once Again Slashes the Price of Core Series SSDs]</ref><ref>[http://www.bit-tech.net/hardware/2008/12/03/g-skill-patriot-and-intel-ssd-test/10 G.Skill, Intel & Patriot SSD group test]</ref> The performance problem was attributed to the small buffer size used in the controller.<ref>[http://www.tomshardware.com/news/ssd-jmicron-jmf602,7057.html Avoid SSDs with Jmicron's JMF602 Controller]</ref> Some manufacturers tried to get around the problem by using 2 JMicron controllers and added more cache, but this increased the cost and still failed to deliver the improved performance.<ref>[http://www.tomshardware.com/news/super-talent-intel-ssd,7978.html Super Talent Claims Its SSDs Can Rock Intel's]</ref> In June 2008, JMicron released version B of the affected controllers, which claimed to improve write latency and allow reserving more spare blocks to overcome the issue,<ref name="DailyTech">{{cite news | url=http://www.dailytech.com/Exclusive+Interview+With+JMicron+on+SSD+Controllers/article14004.htm | first=Jansen | last=Ng | title=Exclusive Interview With JMicron on SSD Controllers | date=22 January 2009 | publisher=[[DailyTech]] | accessdate = 2009-01-23 }}</ref> but Anandtech's test showed that although JMF602B has twice the cache of the JMF602A controller and has less stutter, 4KB random write has 74x the latency and under 2% write speed of Western Digital VelociRaptor 300GB.<ref>[http://anandtech.com/storage/showdoc.aspx?i=3531 The SSD Anthology: Understanding SSDs and New Drives from OCZ]</ref>
JMicron's [[solid-state drive|SSD]] [[Flash memory controller|controller]] is widely adopted by many SSD manufacturers such [[ASUS Eee PC]], [[Corsair Memory|Corsair]],<ref>http://www.hardwaresecrets.com/news/4585</ref> [[OCZ]], and [[Transcend]]. JMicron was the first{{Citation needed|date=March 2009}} company to provide an SSD controller chip to these companies, allowing them to produce reasonably priced [[MLC]] SSDs. JMicron was to announce a new SSD controller with a DRAM cache in Q3 2009,<ref name="DailyTech"/> but no such announcement occurred.
JMF602 would be succeeded by JMF612.<ref>[http://www.dailytech.com/SSD+Prices+Could+be+Cut+in+Half+Due+to+New+JMicron+Flash+Controller++32nm+NAND+Flash/article14176.htm SSD Prices Could be Cut in Half Due to New JMicron Flash Controller & 32nm NAND Flash]</ref>
==Linux Compatibility== JMicron SATA/IDE controllers are often incompatible with some boot loaders. In particular, those using [[GNU GRUB|GRUB]], such as [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]], cannot boot in some conditions (2006/08, 2.6.17).<ref>[https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/57502 Bug #57502: JMicron PATA/SATA Controller does not work]</ref> The 2.6.18 Linux kernel and JMicron controller BIOS 1.06.53<ref>[http://www.jmicron.com/Support_FAQ.html JMicron FAQ]</ref> solved these incompatibilities, but may not be present in existing products, or may require re-flashing the motherboard BIOS. Other bootloaders such as the [[Windows]] [[NTLDR]] boot loader and [[EXTLINUX]] work fine. It has been fixed by the latest distros.
== Security breach == According to the comprehensive analysis of [[Stuxnet]] virus released by Symantec in 2011<ref>[http://www.symantec.com/content/en/us/enterprise/media/security_response/whitepapers/w32_stuxnet_dossier.pdf | W32.Stuxnet Dossier - Version 1.4 (February 2011)]</ref>, a JMicron's digital certificate for Windows got compromised, allowing attacker to digitally sign malicious drivers, then revoked by [[Verisign]] : ''"The attackers would have needed to obtain the digital certificates from someone who may have physically entered the premises of the two companies'' [ [[Realtek]] and JMicron] ''and stole them, as the two companies are in close physical proximity."'' states the report.
==Products== JMicron makes products for a number of different applications, including:
* PATA-SATA translation Bridge * USB-ATA bridge * 1394+USB-SATA bridge * PCI-Express-ATA bridge * PCI Express-1394 bridge * SATA Port Multiplier/Selector with RAID * PCI Express-Ethernet bridge * USB+SATA flash controller * SSD controller
